lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can read a short text about a jumble sale and find key details such as items and adjectives.
supportStrategies: (Reading) Read the text aloud slowly. Ask: “What item is old? What item is big?” Students underline adjectives and nouns in the SB.
stretchStrategies: Jumble Sale Role-Play – Divide students into buyers and sellers. Sellers describe their items using size/age adjectives (“This is an old bag. It’s small.”). Buyers ask questions (“Is it big?” “Is it new?”). Rotate roles. No props needed—just words and imagination.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can trace and write the letters f, u, b, j to form simple words.
supportStrategies: (Phonics) Say and write the letters f, u, b, j. Have students chant each one, then practise writing them on paper or whiteboards.
stretchStrategies: Jumble Sale Role-Play – Divide students into buyers and sellers. Sellers describe their items using size/age adjectives (“This is an old bag. It’s small.”). Buyers ask questions (“Is it big?” “Is it new?”). Rotate roles. No props needed—just words and imagination.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can say one fact about jumble sales and explain that people sell their personal items there.
supportStrategies: (Social Studies) Show a photo of a jumble sale. Ask: “What can you sell?” “Do you have this in your country?” Use pictures to prompt.

items: Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
